title: Rounded Typography
content:
Hello ¡¡  
somebody knows this rounded typography?

Thanks

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024012020im_/http:/typophile.com/files/483368876_1f1647652f_6555.jpg)
author: marcosdopico

comments.content:
ITC/Linotype's Frankfurter is very close, but might not be quite it.  
 [http://www.linotype.com/462/frankfurter-family.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024012020/http:/www.linotype.com/462/frankfurter-family.html "http://www.linotype.com/462/frankfurter-family.html")

Could be custom for the organization. Other options are [Bryant](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024012020/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/process/bryant_medium_alt_no_3/&sample_text=commun%C4%B1ty&sample_size=74) and [FF Speak](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024012020/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/fontfont/ff_speak_heavy/&sample_text=commun%C4%B1ty&sample_size=74).

It's pretty close to [Bryant 2](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024012020/http:/www.processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/bryant2/index.html) based on these stylistic alternative forms:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024012020im_/http:/typophile.com/files/fea_alternates_5546.gif)

course, the "y" isn't the same, so I'd side with Stephen and say it's custom.
